newsitem.title: FRANCE: France heading for record grain harvest in 1996.
newsitem.headline: France heading for record grain harvest in 1996.

text.p: France should harvest a bumper grain crop this year, reaching and possibly exceeding the record 60.4 million tonnes produced in 1992, the French grain cooperatives association (FFCAT) predicted on Monday.
France produced 52.9 million tonnes of grain in 1995.

"If the maize crop confirms its potential, 1996/97 grain output could reach the (record) level for 1992/93 (60.4 million tonnes), the last campaign before reform of the Common Agricultural Policy..," FFCAT said in its weekly newsletter.
"...It could even exceed that level, according to certain official sources," FFCAT added.
France's wheat growers association AGPB predicted last week a 4.2 million tonne jump in the wheat crop to a record 34 million tonnes in 1996.
According to industry sources, France's grain office ONIC is targeting a wheat crop of 33.8 million tonnes while the farm ministry sees 34.3 million tonnes.
FFCAT said prospects for a promising grain crop in France and the rest of the European Union should undermine prices.
French wheat lost 15 francs per tonne over the week as news the country was heading towards a record crop started to emerge.
FFCAT also said early indications suggest the EU grain crop may jump 10-12 percent from 174.2 million tonnes in 1995.

Demand for prompt standard French wheat has dried up as traditional buyers in the north of the EU face ample supplies at home. But demand for French quality wheat remains strong due to quality concerns in German and British wheat. --Paris newsroom +331 4221 5432
